evidence.pdf_reference: filter ( 400 nm) was used as light source, standard calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode, and Pt slice as counter electrode. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor was carried out in a reactor connected with mechanical vacuum pump.The powder of photocatalysts (20 mg) was evenly deposited on a circular quartz plate with diameter of 50 cm and then located inside the photo-reactor perpendicular to the light beam.A 500 W Xe lamp (Oriel) coupled with UV cut-off filter was used as light

Nanosized metallic copper could be a replacement of noble metals for improving photoactivity of TiO 2 -based photocatalysts, but it tends to be oxidized by oxygen in surroundings.To avoid this, black TiO 2 -coated Cu nanoparticles (denoted as CuTiO 2 ) were constructed in the present work, and their photoactivity for the photoreaction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor under visible-light irradiation was explored.X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy and selected area electron diffraction analysis for

in an equilibrium of electron transfer between metallic Cu and TiO 2 .Based on the analysis, it could be said that the presence of metallic Cu facilitates photo-generated electron-hole pairs separation in CuTiO 2 , as evidenced by transient photocurrent measurement.Therefore, the increased photo-generated charge separation in the work should be another reason for the enhanced activity of CuTiO 2 for the reduction of CO 2 . Stability of a catalyst is an important criterion for evaluating its superiority.The

the adsorption of CO 2 on their surface.Furthermore, the metallic Cu increases photoinduced charge-separation of TiO 2 through trapping electrons as evidenced by transient photocurrent measurements.The present work sheds light on developing new type of metal-oxide based visible-light-driven photocatalysts.

evaluating its superiority.The activity of 4 CuTiO 2 was monitored for four successive cycles.As shown in Fig. 9, slight decrease in activity is observed.In addition, two control experiments were performed: (1) visible light irradiation in the absence of catalyst, and (2) irradiation of catalyst and H 2 O vapor with visible light in the absence of Fig. 8.The yields of CO (A) and CH4 (B) products under visible light irradiation for the TiO2, 1 CuTiO2, 2 CuTiO2 and 4 CuTiO2 photocatalysts in CO2H2O(g).CO 2

and the coverage of CO 2 was measured until the equilibrium pressure reached about 9 kP a .The uptake of CO 2 for the saturation coverage on a photo-catalyst surface was determined by extrapolating the coverage of isotherm to P CO 2 0.
